metadata.title: Adding a document browser to your app | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page explaining how to implement a document browser in iOS/iPadOS apps using UIDocumentBrowserViewController. The document covers configuration, customization, and related APIs for giving users access to local and remote documents.
metadata.copyright: Copyright 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

items.text: Adding a document browser to your app

content.text: Adding a document browser to your app
Give users access to their local or remote documents from within your app.
Use a document browser view controller as the root of your app's view hierarchy. When a user selects a document, you present its view controller modally from your document browser.

content.title: Document Browser View Hierarchy
content.description: A layered diagram showing the view hierarchy relationship between Document, Document browser, and App window. The layers are displayed as overlapping parallelograms (3D perspective cards) with the Document layer on top, Document browser in the middle, and App window at the bottom.

nodes.label: Document
nodes.semanticRole: The document view controller presented modally on top

nodes.label: Document browser
nodes.semanticRole: The UIDocumentBrowserViewController as root view controller

nodes.label: App window
nodes.semanticRole: The UIWindow containing the view hierarchy

content.narrativeWalkthrough: The diagram illustrates a three-layer view hierarchy where the App window forms the base layer (gray), the Document browser sits on top of it as the root view controller (yellow/gold), and the Document is presented modally on the topmost layer (green). This visual representation emphasizes that the document browser must be the root view controller, with documents presented modally above it.

content.bodyText:
Always assign the document browser as your app's root view controller. Don't place the document browser in a navigation controller, tab bar, or split view, and don't present the document browser modally.

If you want to present a document browser from another location in your view hierarchy, use a UIDocumentPickerViewController instead.

content.text: The browser automatically gives users the option to share documents using the Share button or a drag-and-drop action. It also provides a standard interface for browsing and managing documents.
You set the type of documents that the user can select when the browser is first created. You can also set the browser's appearance, modify its behaviors, and add custom actions.

items.title: UIDocumentViewController
items.description: A view controller that manages and presents a document stored locally or in the cloud.

items.title: UIDocumentBrowserViewController
items.description: A view controller for browsing and performing actions on documents that you store locally and in the cloud.

items.title: UIDocumentPickerViewController
items.description: A view controller that provides access to documents or destinations outside your app's sandbox.

items.title: UIDocumentInteractionController
items.description: A view controller that previews, opens, or prints files with a file format that your app can't handle directly.

pages.pageSummary: This Apple Developer Documentation page explains how to add a document browser to an iOS/iPadOS app using UIDocumentBrowserViewController. It covers the view hierarchy requirements (document browser must be root), configuration topics (setting up, presenting documents, enabling sharing), customization options (appearance, behaviors, custom actions), and related APIs (UIDocumentViewController, UIDocumentPickerViewController, UIDocumentInteractionController). The page includes a layered diagram showing the proper view hierarchy and an important callout warning about the root view controller requirement.

crossPageElements.runningHeaders: Documentation navigation bar with Apple Developer branding
crossPageElements.runningFooters: Site-wide footer with platform links, tools, resources, programs, and legal information

sections.title: Overview
sections.summary: Introduces the document browser view controller as the root of an app's view hierarchy, explains modal presentation of selected documents, and describes automatic sharing capabilities.

sections.title: Topics - Configuration
sections.summary: Links to three configuration articles: setting up a document browser app, presenting selected documents, and enabling document sharing.

sections.title: Topics - Customization
sections.summary: Links to two customization articles: customizing the browser appearance/behavior and adding custom actions/activities.

sections.title: See Also - Documents and directories
sections.summary: Related documentation including launch customization, directory access, sample code projects, and four UIKit document-related view controller classes.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with a high-level overview explaining the document browser's role and architectural requirements, supported by a visual diagram. An important callout emphasizes the critical constraint that the browser must be the root view controller. The document then organizes related subtopics into Configuration and Customization categories, followed by a See Also section with related documentation and API references.

keyTerms.definition: A view controller for browsing and performing actions on documents that you store locally and in the cloud.
A view controller that provides access to documents or destinations outside your app's sandbox. Use this when you need a document browser at a non-root location in the view hierarchy.
A view controller that manages and presents a document stored locally or in the cloud.
A view controller that previews, opens, or prints files with a file format that your app can't handle directly.
The topmost view controller in an app's view hierarchy, directly assigned to the window. The document browser must serve as the root view controller.
A presentation style where a view controller is displayed on top of another, typically covering the screen. Documents are presented modally from the document browser.

keyFindings: Document browser must be the root view controller - never embed it in navigation controllers, tab bars, split views, or present it modally
When a user selects a document, present its view controller modally from the document browser
Use UIDocumentPickerViewController instead if you need document browser functionality at a non-root location
The browser automatically provides Share button and drag-and-drop for document sharing
Document types must be specified when the browser is first created
Browser appearance, behaviors, and custom actions can be configured after creation

technicalSpecifications.minimumDeploymentTarget: iOS (version not specified on this page)
technicalSpecifications.viewHierarchyRequirement: Document browser must be window's root view controller

designDecisions.decision: Document browser as root view controller
designDecisions.rationale: Ensures consistent document browsing experience and proper integration with system file providers and cloud storage
Allows the browser to remain in the view hierarchy for easy navigation back to file selection
Offers flexibility for apps that need document selection from non-root locations in their navigation
